active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate how forward secrecy in WPA3 via SAE addresses WPA2's PSK vulnerabilities (e.g., KRACK, offline brute-force). Consider implications for personal vs. enterprise networks and future post-quantum readiness. Support claims with references to IEEE 802.11 standards.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in 'Forward Secrecy in WPA3' (Topic Hierarchy: Level 1 Cybersecurity → Level 2 001_Cryptography → Level 3 001_Cryptographic Protocols → Level 4 004_Wireless Security Protocols → Level 5 WPA3 Security Enhancements → Level 6 Forward Secrecy in WPA3). Use university pedagogy: Bloom's Taxonomy objectives [insert list above], 4-layer scaffolding [insert scaffolding above], active learning ties [reference activities for engagement]. Incorporate research: FS via SAE (Dragonfly key exchange, RFC 7664), protects past sessions post-compromise, addresses WPA2 PSK flaws (offline attacks). Big picture: Advances WPA3 toward robust wireless security. Concept map: FS → SAE → Dragonfly → Session Keys. Standards: IEEE 802.11-2016, Wi-Fi Alliance. Prior knowledge: WPA2 vulnerabilities. Generate 25 high-quality flashcards following this exact JSON schema per card: {'type': 'MCQ|Cloze|etc.', 'bloom_level': 'Remember|etc.', 'scaffolding_layer': 1-4, 'front': 'Question text', 'back': {'answer': '...', 'explanation': '... Ensure active recall, no cues on front. Output as JSON array of 25 flashcards. End with self-assessment: 'Rate your FS understanding pre/post (1-5) and note one new insight.'
